enchantment.survive.cooling.desc: Drops your temperature when wearing this armor
enchantment.survive.adjusted_cooling.des: Automatically reduces your temperature whenever it is hot
enchantment.survive.warming.desc: Raises your temperature when wearing this armor
enchantment.survive.adjusted_warming.des: Automatically increases your temperature whenever it is cold
enchantment.survive.featherweight.desc: Reduces the weight of the armor piece by 18% per level
enchantment.survive.weightless.desc: Makes the armor piece feel weightless to the wearer

gui.survive.config.title: Survive Config
power.survive.heat_resistance.name: Heat Resistance
power.survive.heat_resistance.descriptio: You are almost immune to really high temperatures
power.survive.cold_blooded.name: Cold Blooded
power.survive.cold_blooded.description: You have a higher than average resistance to changes in temperature
text.survive.survival_guide.landing: This book acts like a wiki of sorts and gives you basic information on how certain mechanics in this mod works
book.survive.category.food.name: Hunger & Thirst
book.survive.category.food.desc: Tips on how to manage your hunger and thirst
book.survive.category.stamina.name: Stamina
book.survive.category.stamina.desc: Tips on how to manage your stamina and avoid overworking yourself
book.survive.entry.overeating.name: Overeating/drinking
book.survive.entry.overeating.page.1: This mod grants the ability to eat and drink beyond the capacity of your stomach which unfortunately means you'll need to watch the amount you attempt to stuff down your throat. The feature can be disabled in the server configuration files, but if you do decide to play along here are the details of how the feature works. If you're familiar with vanilla
book.survive.entry.overeating.page.2: then you'd know that the maximum amount of hunger points you're able to get is 20, this feature changes it by raising that limit to 40 but with a catch. The moment your hunger goes beyond 20, you get a "Stomach Ache" debuff which reduces your movement speed. For every 4 points above 20 that you go, you get an extra stack of the debuff and if you hit 40, you start to take severe damage. With all the downsides of this feature, there is one singular upside.
book.survive.entry.overeating.page.3: If you fill your hunger bar to exactly 20 points, you get a "Well Fed" buff which increases your stamina regeneration and grants a very slight movement and attack buff while it's active. The same applies to thirst, with the exception of the "Well Fed" buff
book.survive.entry.spoiling.name: Spoiling
book.survive.entry.spoiling.page.1: A feature that comes with this mod is the ability for food to go bad. this also comes with the added caveat that food no longer stacks. Each food item now has a set amount of time that they would last for, and if they're not consumed before this time elapses, they go bad. There are 5 possible states for every food item, each providing their own benefits. The first is $(fresh) and is the first state of any food item. This state lasts for 5 minutes, or
book.survive.entry.spoiling.page.2: half an ingame day, and will provide you with half as much saturation as the meal would normally provide. The next status is $(good) and which pops up the moment the $(fresh) status expires. This lasts for 10 minutes or a whole ingame day and increases the saturation provided by 10%%. The next state after that is $(okay) and will often be the state the food item is in the longest. This provides no added benefits to your food.
book.survive.entry.spoiling.page.3: Next up is the $(spoiling) status and this shows up a full day before the food transitions to the $(spoiled) status. The only adverse effect if this status is that you lose 10%% saturation on your food. The final status for your food is $(spoiled) and this reduces the saturation and hunger replenished by your food by half. You also get the Hunger and Nausea effects for one minute upon consumption, and if you have the Wellness module enabled, will cause you to fall ill
book.survive.entry.armor_weight.name: Armor Weight
book.survive.entry.armor_weight.page.1: As this mod gives you stamina which depletes when you take specific actions in the game and refunds some stamina when you take rest or eat specific foods, what you wear can affect your passive stamina restoration. Whenever you wear armor, the amount of stamina you regain is reduced by a certain percentage and if you go over 21kg of weight (can be configured in your stamina config), your stamina starts
book.survive.entry.armor_weight.page.2: to deplete instead. By default, Iron armor will get you to exactly this number, so you will not regain stamina passively if you fully deck yourself out with iron armor. Watch the weight of what you wear, and if it ever goes beyond 21kg (or your custom limit), take the armor off and take a break from wearing it for a while.
